text: Twelve-year-old COLLETTE MCVEIGH is absorbed in making a necklace with a bucket of beads. She’s listening to 10CC’ hit single Rubber Bullets on the gramophone. Load up, load up the rubber bullets...
COLLETTE’S father, GERRY SENIOR, puts his head around the door. He has interrupted a call and has his hand over the receiver.

Get us some fags love. Your mother’s run out. He disappears again. COLLETTE continues with her fun a moment, then stands and walks through to the... INT. KITCHEN - CONTINUOUS. ..-where her seven-year-old brother SEAN is eating a bowl of cereal. He’s a cute-looking kid, the baby of the famil
Dad wants you to get some fags.
He asked you.
Doesn’t matter. I went last time. SEAN rolls his eyes. Sisters.

SEAN emerges into the street, leaving the door open so th 10CC’s song comes with us. He instinctively turns left for the shop, but then checks himself. There’s a huge riot at the other end of the street. Curiosity gets the better of him and he heads towards it. Some kids are playing football. Parents gossip in the doorways; every day life in a city torn apart by civil strife.

SEAN’s P.O.V. as he steps out into the fringe of the riot He can just make out his older brothers GERRY and PADDY with masks around their faces, throwing tear gas at the soldiers. The troops are using armoured Land Rovers as barricades. A bus is burning. One hell of a playground. 10CC have got to the chorus again. Load up, load up the rubber bullets... Wham! He’s hit. On the ground. Silence. PADDY and GERRY running towards him. A crowd gathering... Why can’t he hear anything? What’s happening?

As the sound CRASHES BACK, GERRY and PADDY are stumbling down the street with SEAN in their arms. They are surrounded by rioters, onlookers, neighbors... Chaos. Shouts. Voices. It’s Sean. Aye, it’s wee Sean. Jes Christ, it's Sean. Bastards! They've shot wee Sean! INT. COLLETTE’S PARENTS HOME - THE KITCHEN - CONTINUOUS. The crowd tumbles in.
Mal GERRY lays his baby brother gently down on the floor.
Dad! He bends over him.

Jesus, Sean. Speak to me!  3. GERRY SENIOR and SEAN’s MOTHER appear in the doorway. MA white as a sheet as GERRY SENIOR thrusts the others aside He takes SEAN’s pulse. Tries CPR. Nothing. Tries again. The room grows quiet. MA falls to her knees. MA. Speak to me Sean. Silence. A hand on his cheek.

Speak to me, my boy. He’s dead. She puts her arms around him and draws him to her chest. She starts to cry. It’s gut-wrenching, heart-breaking... GERRY SENIOR catches sight of COLLETTE’s stunned face in the throng. He yanks her into the...
..-where she retreats from his fury. They stare at each other.

(quietly) What happened? No answer. GERRY SENIOR (CONT’D) I asked you to go. No answer. GERRY SENIOR (CONT’D) (louder) Why wasn’t it you? She takes a few more paces back. GERRY SENIOR (CONT’D) It should have been you! He pushes her into...
.--and slams the door. The noise recedes. Terror in her eyes. Desolation. Isolation. Silence again. Until we can just make out her breathing... FADE TO BLACK.

head_text.subj: IN THE DARK, THE SOUND OF BREATHING AGAIN, BUT THIS TIME

text: MOTION -- she’s running flat out -- cops chasing -- siren wailing. This is COLLETTE MCVEIGH aged 31; widow, mother, sister, bomber. And strikingly BEAUTIFUL. She is weaving through a stunned crowd on the station concourse, carrying a BLACK BAG over her shoulder.
JOE MACINTOSH -- MAC -- stands in front of a bunch of screens. He’s 40s, tall, rugged; a bull of a man. No doub he’s in control here.

Give me the walkway... EXT. LONDON STREET - CONTINUOUS. COLLETTE is sprinting -- like her life depends on it -- over the road bridge. There are undercover detectives behind, uniforms and cop cars below and a chopper overhea Down the steps. Off the sidewalk and head to head with an oncoming car. The driver slams his fist on his horn.
(through an open window) For fuck’s sake! EXT. MI5 CONTROL ROOM - CONTINUOUS.
Six come east. EXT. WESTMINSTER SKYLINE - CONTINUOUS. A helicopter SWOOPS LOW. INT. HELICOPTER - CONTINUOUS. CLOSE on the monitor. We can just make out COLLETTE runni across...

.».-where she throws her bag over the side. CLOSE as it HITS THE WATER. EXT. CONTROL ROOM - CONTINUOUS. (looking at shot from helicopter monitor) The bag please, Danny... EXT. WESTMINSTER BRIDGE - NORTH SIDE - CONTINUOUS. She swings right -- down the steps -- smashing through tourists to... INT. WESTMINSTER TUBE STATION - CONTINUOUS. ..-where she vaults the barrier. INT. CONTROL ROOM - CONTINUOUS.
We need all platforms...now... The screens are slow coming up.
C'mon guys.... The central station monitor pings through -- now we can s undercover cops leaping the ticket barriers.
Hold back...I don’t want it done here. Platform cameras on stream. She emerges into sight of one
Circle line westbound...how long ‘till the next train?

Cops pile onto the platform. CLOSE on COLLETTE. That haunted, hunted look again. She's not going to be caught. She stares ahead into the dark tunnel. She’s not...she wouldn't... She’s onto the track and in. INT. CONTROL ROOM - CONTINUOUS.

Shit! She’s on the track...shut it down -- all of it...the whole network. INT. TUBE TUNNEL - CONTINUOUS. COLLETTE running through the dark... INT. CONTROL ROOM - CONTINUOUS. A screen map of the tube from control on one of the monitors. There’s a train in the tunnel. INT. TUBE TUNNEL - CONTINUOUS. A rumble in the distance, a flash of lights.
MAC grabs the receiver.
(eyes glued to the screen, voice icy calm) It’s Joe Macintosh here. (MORE )
We've got a target on the line. Pull the plug! A beat. The guy’s trying to argue the toss...

That's a straight order. Right. Now. INT. TUBE TUNNEL - CONTINUOUS. Thunderous noise and bright lights as the train HURTLES closer. COLLETTE turns back, but too late. It’ll smash he to pieces for sure... A service alcove. She’s in. Train whips past. Thwup, thwup. Gone. Now screeching to a halt... A beat. Collette tries to recover her breathing. Her face is covered in sweat. Rats screech at her feet. She's running again... INT. CONTROL ROOM - CONTINUOUS. MAC's eyes on the screen. The train has stopped. He takes the phone.
Did the driver hit anything?
Hold on.
We don’t have time to hold on.
No...no. He’s shaken up. He saw someone running, but he didn’t... MAC slams down the receiver.
Where’s next on the line?
St James’s Park.

Then let’s see it!  INT. ST JAMES’S PARK TUBE STATION - CONTINUOUS. COLLETTE, accompanied by a few rats, emerges from the tunnel and jumps onto the platform. She walks normally, like it’s the most natural thing in the world, past a few startled passengers. INT. CONTROL ROOM - CONTINUOUS. Screens coming up. Nothing on the platforms. MAC catches a glimpse of her as she slips from view in th station entrance.

She’s out. Leaving St James’s Park station... EXT. ST JAMES’S PARK TUBE STATION - CONTINUOUS. COLLETTE walks calmly towards a woman who has just starte up her Vespa and is adjusting her helmet. At the last minute, she charges -- thrusts the woman off picks up the Vespa, speeds away... EXT. PARLIAMENT SQUARE - CONTINUOUS. Cops cars streaming past the Commons, sirens wailing... EXT. ST JAMES’S PARK - CONTINUOUS. COLLETTE bombing across the bridge over the lake... EXT. THE MALL —- CONTINUOUS. A fleet of sirens tearing down towards BUCKINGHAM PALACE as... COLLETTE whips across in front of them. The cop cars SCREECH to a halt and follow into GREEN PARK INT. CONTROL ROOM - CONTINUOUS.

Four and five go north of Piccadilly, three west.  EXT. GREEN PARK - CONTINUOUS. COLLETTE reaches the pavement at the top of the park -- scattering pedestrians. She skids -- almost falls. Onto t road. Cars screech to a halt. Into the narrow streets the far side... INT. CONTROL ROOM - CONTINUOUS.

We need to take her here...this is it guys. EXT. BERKELEY STREET - CONTINUOUS. It’s a one way street. COLLETTE swings against the traffi and accelerates down the pavement, scattering terrified shoppers. EXT. CONTROL ROOM - CONTINUOUS. C1OSE on the monitor with the helicopter feed. Go WIDER t see MAC watching the moving electronic dot on the map in front of him.

Four block off Davies Street. Five come down Grosvenor. EXT. DAVIES ST - CONTINUOUS. COLLETTE sees a car across the street ahead. She comes to halt. Turns around. Another screams up behind. Men in raincoats pour out, pistols raised. No escape.
Get in. They push her roughly into the car. And tear away. INT. CONTROL ROOM - CONTINUOUS.
Package onboard. Inbound.  10.

(to his colleagues) Okay, keep the uniform boys on the ground. Tell the press we’re hunting a clean skin. Make sure the picture you put out is blurred enough to obscure her ID. INT. CELL - PADDINGTON GREEN POLICE STATION - NIGHT. COLLETTE faces two cops. Two audio tapes turn in the recording device on the table.
Boy are you in the shit, sweetheart. No answer. Cop 1 flips open a file on the desk and pushes across a photograph of COLLETTE hugging her five-year-old son in the rear garden of a terrace house.
Cute kid...did you tell him you might not be coming back? He smiles bitterly.
Train to Dublin. He spins around a picture of her seated in the carriage. Then more surveillance photos in quick succession;
Ferry to Fishguard. South to a safe house in Oxford. Two days to kick your heels. Winchester. The courier leaves you a rucksack, two kilos of semtex and a TPU. A beat.
Onto the train. Flick the timer and you’re ready to go. But now we've got the bag and the bomb and you bang to rights. So boo fucking hoo.
(leaning) Shame about your boy, love. No answer.  ll.
Twenty-five years; out in eighteen if you keep your nose clean. You'll be lucky if he remembers your name.
MAC has been watching the interrogation through the one-w glass. The two detectives file out. MAC picks
Good enough?
Fine.
Shout if you need anything else. up a briefcase and enters. INT. POLICE CELL - CONTINUOUS. He closes A beat. MAC flips cassettes the door.
Can I get you anything?
A lawyer. open the tape recorder on the desk, removes the and throws them into a drawer. COLLETTE (CONT’D) I'm legally entitled to speak to--

I know what you’re entitled to, Collette. But you just tried to go head to head with a five hundred ton tube train, so do us both a favour and listen. You don’t want to be here. And I can get you out. He opens the briefcase, takes out a file. It has SEAN MICHAEL MCVEIGH. SHOT 25th JUNE 1973 MINISTRY OF DEFENCE CONFIDENTIAL stamped on the front.  12.

It won’t give you what you want, or what your family’s lawyers expect. But maybe it’1l help. He closes his briefcase, leaves. INT. OBSERVATION ROOM - CONTINUOUS. He watches from the other side of the glass. She stares a the file like it’s a contagious disease. He walks around the corner, gets a cup of coffee and slip out to the... INT. STAIRWELL - CONTINUOUS. ...-where he lights a cigarette and leans against the window. Footsteps. One of his colleagues with the video grab. Sur enough, it’s pretty hard to say definitively that’s COLLETTE.
Fine. Lay it on thick. Police tonight are still hunting--

Sure, Mac. We got it. INT. CELL - CONTINUOUS. COLLETTE staring at the file. She breathes in deep and opens it. Shit. Page one; Sean’s naked corpse on the slab. She shuts her eyes. INT. OBSERVATION ROOM - A FEW MINUTES LATER. MAC at his desk, watching the news. Some reporter outside Waterloo Station;

Trevor, the government continues to insist the IRA is serious about peace, but it’s hard to believe that when they’re sending young women over here to plant-- He kills the sound.  13. Stands, to get a glimpse through the glass.

COLLETTE’S P.O.V. as she looks at a photograph of two men throwing petrol bombs. Their faces are shielded by scarve but their names are written in white ink; GERRY MCVEIGH. PADDY MCVEIGH. SEAN can just be seen emerging from the side street. INT. CELL - CONTINUOUS. MAC slips in. COLLETTE closes the file. He takes it, puts it in his briefcase, sits.
I don’t know who you are, but I have nothing to say to you. MAC takes out another file. He holds up a photograph.
Remember him? She lowers her gaze.
Look at it, please. She won't.
Look at it, Collette. No way.
Raymond Quinn. You used to work at his print factory. No answer.
You told Paddy he was a part-time soldier and this was the result. A picture of a BODY LYING AMIDST KIDS TOYS...
You scouted it, Gerry ordered it and Paddy pulled the trigger. Raymond's wife found their kids clinging to the corpse.  Nothing. 14.
Two months ago at his grave... A photograph of her placing flowers in front of a headstone. No answer.
You want to tell me why, Collette?
There’s no shame in remorse, you know. Not for any of us. Another folder. He drops it onto the desk. No No No No
(sighs) Provisional forensics. response. answer. answer. answer.
Not one for the boyos back home, eh?
(steely) That would lead to a lot of awkward questions.
(flicking through) What were you planning to tell them? That their kit didn’t work? That you were being followed? He leans forward.
You didn’t set the timer, Collette! This thing couldn’t have blown up a fucking paper bag!
I'd like to speak to my lawyer.  15.
You come all the way over here, but you were planning to fire a dud. Why? No answer.
So here’s a girl who puts flowers on a victim’s grave. And who suddenly can’t bring herself to arm the bomb she’s been sent to plant. Still none.
Maybe your brothers would say you're betraying Sean’s memory. But I--

(with a flash of anger; he’s touched a nerve) I have a right to speak to a legal representative! MAC takes a video tape from the briefcase, slaps it into the machine, bangs it shut and presses play. We see a grainy undercover shot of COLLETTE and her five-year-old son MARK walking home from school. She's trying not to watch, but it’s hard. He’s a cute- looking boy. Her son. Her pride and joy. Not much younger than Sean was when he died. The tape goes on rolling...and rolling. We can just make out his voice now, chattering to her. COLLETTE turns away. She’s a soldier of war. Like her brothers. Just got to hold on... God, it’s hard. Bastard.

(quietly) You know what it’s going to be like; an Irish girl in an English jail. Every time you want to see your boy, his grandmother will have to load him onto a ferry and drive four hundred miles. It’1ll break his heart. A beat.  16.

Maybe we can talk to our friends in the social services. See if we can have him put up for adoption. After all, he’d surely be better-- COLLETTE reaches forward suddenly to stop the tape and MA seizes her wrist.
Tell me you don’t believe in something better. She tries to withdraw, but he won’t let go.
You can have it. She struggles free. He sits back.
(sighs) Maybe your leaders are serious about peace this time. We have to believe that. But your brother Gerry will kill it off if he possibly can. Is that what you want? No answer.

You agree to talk to us, to watch him, and you’re out of here like nothing ever happened. Back to your Mother. Back to your boy. We'll pay you. Well. And one day, if you want it, we can give you a life far away from this.
I'd like to call my lawyer now.
This is the road you took when you put flowers on Raymond Quinn’s grave, Collette. It’s the road you took when you decided not to arm that--
(exasperated) You don’t know a damned thing! A beat. He looks at her. Hard.  17.

I know it bugs the hell out of you your mother won’t get the washing machine fixed. I know you ask yourself why your boy still wets his bed at night. I know you were so lonely the evening before you came here that you went home with a guy you don’t even like. I know he fucked you so roughly that--
(on her feet, pushing the table back) For Christ’s sake--
(on his feet also) You went back to your mother’s place, took your son into your arms and cried until it was time to leave.
I want. To speak. To a--
Jesus! You people have no sense of irony. He scoops up the files and puts them back in his briefcas The interview is over.
If you want to take your anger to the grave, be my guest. But you can be fucking sure you'll take your son with you. He’s at the door.
You have two hours. After that, you're on your own. If you really want a lawyer, press the button on my side of the desk.

It’s a filthy, windswept evening. MAC’s boss KATE FLETCHE stands by the door of a pavilion. She’s extremely attractive, but dresses to hide it. She’s calm, focused, little icy, even. She’s considerably younger than MAC.  18. Some of her officers lurk in the hedgerows. A car guns do the lane, lights spinning in the darkness. A little rat o a man named GINGY HUGHES steps out.

(like a mother scolding her son) You're late. They step into the... INT. PAVILION - CONTINUOUS. .--and sit close on a bench. The wind whistles through th rafters and worries at the windows. GINGY squirms, part supplicant, part child, part suitor. He is highly agitate
They’re onto me. She takes his hand. His mother now.
Gingy--
Mulgrew was here.
Doing what?
Watching. He came down two days ago.
He talked to you?
No, but--

Gingy, it’s okay. She leans closer, grips him a little tighter. A woman who is not afraid to use her femininity... FLETCHER (CONT’D) We need you, Gingy. More than ever. You know that. If McVeigh and Fox are linking up... He closes his eyes. He doesn’t want to do this. There is something impressive and, at the same time, completely grotesque about the way she holds him in place  19. A hard woman to break free from. In every way. The wind rattles the windows and they look around, but it nothing. Just a ghost in the night.
MAC and the DUTY OFFICER are watching COLLETTE through th glass window.
She’s not touched the button, sir. Hasn’t moved a muscle. MAC nods.

A sallow young man, EDDIE MCILHATTON, watches a woman wal out of the COMMONS precinct. He follows her around the corner and down into WESTMINSTER TUBE STATION. He stands behind her as she takes off a security pass and slips it into her handbag.
The woman from the House of Commons is reading a newspape unaware that MCILHATTON is watching her. The tube is emptier. Coming to the end of the line.
MAC sits. She’s not pressed the button. So they both know she’s crossed a line.
You want a cup of coffee now?
You can’t ask me to betray my family. He thinks about this. Betrayal. It’s a big word.
(sighs) We all have our secrets. Little lies we tell ourselves, those we palm off on others. (MORE )

There’s a woman who works at the travel agent on the Andersonstown Road...no more than a girl. You want to see what your brother does to her when Christy thinks he’s on IRA business? He reaches for his briefcase again.
No...no. She's a little shocked by that. Silence.
You'll be keeping people alive, Collette. Boys like your son. Women like you. Men like me. So don’t talk to me about betrayal.
They’11 kill me.
They’11 never know.
They always know.
I'll be there, day and night, watching.
Until you don’t need me any more and then...(clicks her fingers) He looks at her long and hard. It’s a stare that says; if you cross this line, you’re my girl. Period.

The WOMAN from the House of Commons leaves the tube stati and steps onto a dimly-lit street. MCILHATTON closes in o her and flips up the hood of his jacket. He starts to run, RIPS the handbag from her arm and sprin into the night. She is too shocked to scream.  21.
Neither MAC nor COLLETTE has moved. He’s leaning on the desk, like they’re down to business.

You have two weeks to convince us you mean what you say. If you don’t make the grade, you’re back in this chair staring at a charge sheet. Tonight, we put out a blurred grab from the cameras in the train station. Your friends in Belfast will guess it’s you, but it’s vague enough for us to be excused making an ID. That’s your cover. You escaped from the train station, went to ground and hid out overnight. We’ll go through your movements step by step. No answer. MAC. Have you got that, Collette? She nods, but without meeting his eye.
Are you sure you want to do this? No answer. MAC. I need to hear you say it.
(looking up) I’m sure. Hold. The moment of betrayal...but she doesn’t look sure a damned thing.
MCILLHATTON steps into a phone box, dials. A voice answer
Andersonstown Travel.
Wolfe Tone.
Hold on.  22. MCILLHATTON glances over his shoulder.
What is it?

I’ve got what we need. I’1ll take it to the man. The call is cut. EDDIE MCILLHATTON, a little put out, replaces the receiver. He steps out of the phone box, scopes the street. This is a lonely calling. EXT. BATTERSEA PARK - EARLY MORNING. COLLETTE and MAC stand by a shed.

When you got away, you came here. It was too dangerous to call in because the whole city was crawling with cops. MAC takes her arm and leads her gently away. INT. GINGY’S HOUSE - SOUTH ARMAGH - DAY. GINGY kisses his wife and four kids goodbye and heads for the door. He looks hassled and annoyed. Through the windo we see the side of his newly painted van. GINGY HUGHES PLUMBING. Night or day, call 0845 666734.

location: THE BACK SEAT OF A CAR

text: He hands her a sheet of paper.

Memorise the number and the time and place of the first meeting, then burn it. Your code name is SHADOW DANCER. Don’t use the phone in the house unless you are sure there is no one else there. If anyone sees you in a phone box, say it’s a love affair you don’t want your mother to hear about. COLLETTE stares out of the window.
You need this.  23. He hands over a piece of metal and plastic half the size a golf ball.
It’s an emergency bleep. Hide it well. If you press the button, half the world will come running. She takes it, but continues to gaze out of the window.
What’s your name?
My code name is Box Man. If you call in, you ask for--
I mean your real name.
It’s better you don’t know.
If you make a mistake, I’m dead -- right? I’d like to know your name. He hesitates.
My name is Mac. She looks at him, like she’s seeing him for the first tim Who the hell is this guy?

I‘1l see you in Belfast. Make sure you’re at the rendezvous. INT. THE FRONT SEAT OF GINGY’S CAR - DAY GINGY HUGHES is spinning down the road to that pavilion again, but he’s not pleased about it. He parks ups and bristles as he marches inside. INT. THE PAVILION - SOUTH ARMAGH - CONTINUOUS. It’s dark in here, but nothing assuages GINGY’s anger.

What the hell’s the problem? I told you--  24. A torch-light flicks on. It illuminates the ghoulish face of KEVIN MULGREW, the IRA’s new head of Internal Security MULGREW. Mornin’, Gingy. You’se expecting someone else?

(stunned) No...no. GINGY turns to run, but it’s too late. MULGREW’S men have the place surrounded. INT. MI5’S BELFAST HEADQUARTERS - FLETCHER’S OFFICE - DAY KATE FLETCHER is on the phone. One of her junior officers interrupts.
Looks like Blue One is down. A moment of genuine shock on her face, but she recovers.
Tell me.
His wife called the local priest. She was expecting him at the doctor's. The police have found his car. It was at one of the rendezvous points.
I’1l deal with it. He leaves. She shuts the door, closes her eyes. A beat, whilst she gathers herself. She dials. Together again. Composed. FLETCHER (CONT’D) Give me the chief please. It’s Kate.

GINGY HUGHES sits in a chair, naked, with a sack over his head. MULGREW. When, Gingy? MULGREW doesn’t receive an answer, so he yanks GINGY up a drags him to a filthy blood red bath.  25. He smashes his skull against it as GINGY screams in pain. MULGREW plunges his head into the water and holds him dow The rest of the crew watch. They don’t share MULGREW’s sadism. He yanks GINGY’s head up. We notice he is trying to avoid getting dirty water on a new pair of BRIGHT RED TRAINERS. MULGREW. (CONT’D) When did you start your touting?
(terrified) I’m a patriot. I’m just-- GINGY’s P.0.V. as his head goes under.

location: A FERRY ON THE IRISH SEA

text: COLLETTE gazes out across the water. She is on her way ho at last. INT. MI5’S BELFAST HEADQUARTERS - SITUATION ROOM - DAY FLETCHER on the phone.
I want everything you have out there. She listens.
No. They have him. We're sure, yes.
GINGY is back in the chair. MULGREW has put on a pair of leather gloves. MULGREW. Who reeled you in, Gingy?
No one. MULGREW strikes him hard. MULGREW. We have time, Gingy. More time than you’se could ever dream of.  26.

head_text.subj: INT. A TRAIN APPROACHING BELFAST STATION- DAY

text: Smudged images of the city beyond a rain-soaked window. ~ the seat beside COLLETTE a newspaper headline shouts ‘PEA IN OUR TIME? LONDON AND DUBLIN HAIL ‘DOWNING STREET DECLARATION’ .’

A van guns down a dirt track in the driving rain. The doo opens and GINGY HUGHES is pulled out. MULGREW’S men drag him into a nearby field. MULGREW walks behind, trying not to get his trainers muddy. GINGY knows what’s coming. He’ a mumbling, gibbering wreck.
COLLETTE leaves the station. The rain stops. The sun shines. She’s close to home now and can’t contain herself She starts to run...
GINGY is on his knees by a ditch. MULGREW holds a pistol his head.
(crying) Please...for my kids sake... MULGREW. You think we should forgive ye, Gingy?

I beg you... MULGREW. Aye...maybe youse’re right. The quality of mercy should not be strained. What about that? MULGREW touches GINGY’s shoulder paternally, but we see from the faces of his crew that they don’t buy the possibility of a reprieve. CLOSE on the youngest. He looks like he’s about to shit h pants. MULGREW pulls the trigger. GINGY slumps forward, dead. MULGREW turns away. He looks irritably at his shoes to ma sure there is no blood on them.  27. EXT. COLLETTE’S STREET - DAY Motion again -- COLLETTE pounding the pavement. She round the corner, runs past a group of kids playing football in the street and struggles with her key in the lock. She bursts into... INT. COLLETTE’S HOME - CONTINUOUS. The house is quiet. COLLETTE’S MOTHER is hunched over the stove. As she turns, the suffering of the years of war is etched indelibly into her face. MA conducts herself with unbearable dignity. They embrace.
He’s out back.
Is he...
He’s fine. COLLETTE’S P.O.V. as she rushes through to... EXT. BACK YARD - CONTINUOUS. ...-where MARK is kicking a ball against the fence. He se her, stares a moment -- then runs.
Mark! COLLETTE sprints after him into... EXT. ALLEY - CONTINUOUS. Halfway down, she catches up.

Go away! She wrestles with him. He gives in, sobs, clings to her. Tight. Like he’s never going to let go. She presses his head to her neck. She’s home. It’s okay. Everything's all right now. INT. MI5’S BELFAST HEADQUARTERS - FLETCHER’S OFFICE - DAY FLETCHER’S on the phone again.
Where? Are you sure it’s him?  28. She listens.

No, I‘’1l deal with the family. They're our responsibility. Replaces the phone slowly. There’s absolutely no emotion there now. INT. COLLETTE’S HOME - KITCHEN - EVENING An ordinary family scene. MARK is finishing his tea, whil COLLETTE and her MOTHER wash up. The door opens and in wa COLLETTE’S two brothers, GERRY and PADDY. GERRY is taller and older. He is brooding and handsome, with cropped hair naturally a leader. But PADDY got all the emotional intelligence. He is shorter and bulkier with long, unkemp hair and a moustache. There’s a warmth here. They’re a family, right or wrong.
We heard a rumour our girl was back. He hugs his sister and whispers;
It was all over the news. Ma’s been in pieces. He kisses his mother. GERRY takes a hunk of bread off the side and wipes some of the left-over gravy from MARK’s plate. He winks at his sister.

INT. COLLETTE’S HOME - SECONDS LATER. MARK still trying to run after his mother. He’s hysterica MA tries to calm him.
COLLETTE is dragged down a corridor. Detainees’ clothes (concealed by a cloth sack) hang on a peg outside each door. We hear;
I’m Richard McIlwaine, Republican. If you’re Republican, tell ‘em nothing! COLLETTE breaks free and hammers the door.
Richard, it’s Collette!
Hang in there, Collette. Tell ‘em nothing! COLLETTE is roughly man-handled down the corridor and int a cell.
COLLETTE is seated. MAC steps in, closes the door behind him and drops her file on the desk. Waits.
Where were you? No answer. MAC thumps the table so hard she jumps.
I was looking after my son! I...I couldn’t get away! He leans towards her, hands on the desk. COLLETTE (CONT’D) It’s what happened!

I save you from a lifetime ina stinking prison cell. And you’re going to sit here and tell me you didn’t turn up because you couldn't find a fucking nanny! She's shocked. His anger is un-nerving. He sits.  47.

Yes.

You said they wouldn’t be hurt...you promised that. Brushes her hand nervously across it now.

I don’t want ‘of course.’ He’s not going through that hoop again. COLLETTE (CONT’D) (hesitatant) There’s something tomorrow.  48. Go on. She won't.

Paddy’s going to kill the guy...the detective who tried to put us both away for the murder of my boss at the print works. Henderson. He’s a big shot now. CID.

(sighs) Mulgrew’s a cunning piece of shit. He may not come at you right away. So be ready. They wait.

It’s time to go. She continues to gaze out at the black night. She doesn’t want to go. She shivers. He reaches out and closes his hand around her's. A moment. Something here. She does not meet his gaze. COLLETTE steps out and walks rapidly away into the darkness. She does not look back.
